ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS

(Applicants on waiting list)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chng Hee Kok -

    1. To ask the Minister for National Development what is the number of applicants for Housing and Development Board flats on the waiting list and if there are any plans to change HDB's building programme.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st August 1998, there were 108,500 applicants on the waiting list under the Registration for Flat System (RFS). Of these, 42% were first-timers and 58%

Column: 1181

upgraders. Compared with 145,700 applicants in June 1997, the waiting list has dropped by 26%.

    HDB reviewed its building programme in August this year. It will build 22,000 flats in non-mature estates in 1999 as the number of new applications has declined in recent months. Together with replacement flats for the Selective En-Bloc Redevelopment Scheme and studio apartments, HDB has planned for a building programme of 28,500 flats for 1999.

    HDB will continue to monitor the demand and adjust the building programme accordingly. It will also ensure that applicants are invited to book their flats within a reasonable time period.

Column: 1181

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Revision of sale price)


    2. Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will revise the sale price of new HDB flats in view of (i) the drop in values of resale HDB flats and private properties, and (ii) the present economic conditions, in general.

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is committed to provide affordable housing to Singapore citizens, especially first-timers and low-income families, despite the current economic conditions.

    HDB considers several factors in setting prices of new flats. The main one is affordability. HDB prices new flats such that 90% of Singaporean households can afford at least a 3-room flat, and 70% at least a 4-room flat.

    HDB also takes into account individual attributes of the flats such as location, proximity to MRT/LRT stations, the view from the flats, and special design features and finishes. New flats tend to have better designs and finishes, and are located in towns with better facilities and infrastructure.

    HDB does not consider the prices of private residential properties when it sets

Column: 1182

prices of new HDB flats. However, it does factor in current HDB resale market prices, because resale prices are an indication of how willing and able Singaporeans are to pay for HDB flats. Prices of new HDB flats are below the market values of equivalent flats.

    At present prices, new HDB flats continue to be heavily subsidized. The overall sales proceeds do not cover their total development costs. The loss incurred by HDB has to be funded by a Government grant.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, in view of the drop in prices of resale flats, does the HDB take into consideration the so-called market subsidy in setting its price?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, we have debated this before in the House. I have to remind the Member for Hougang that the prices of new flats are heavily subsidised compared to market prices of equivalent flats in the market today.

    Mr J B Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary - and we have heard this before - talks about heavily subsidising HDB flats. Does the HDB publish, every time they embark upon a construction, the cost to the HDB of the construction of that particular estate or block?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, HDB has just released their Annual Report and the CEO of HDB conducted a press conference last weekend. May I refer Members to the financial review pages and they will get all the relevant statistics. In particular, may I refer the Member to the balance sheet and the income statement. The income statement shows quite clearly the losses incurred by the Government in the sale of new flats and this figure was also highlighted by the CEO of HDB. For the year 1997/98 it amounted to $591 million. This is something like 60% of the total deficit incurred by HDB, which was about $1 billion.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not asking for figures in the annual statement of the HDB. I am asking whether it would not be a good thing if the HDB publishes its cost for every development and say at what prices they are going to sell the apartments.

Column: 1183



    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, the development cost of each individual block is not published but if the Member wishes to know the development cost of a particular block or precinct, he is welcome to file a Question in Parliament. The reason why we do not publish these figures is that every precinct has different characteristics. New precincts have got markets and roads at different stages of construction. But the selling prices of new flats are published and made known to the people who are asked to select the flats. But these figures are not state secrets. If he wants to know the development cost we will let him know. But we incurred a great loss because of the total development cost. I think Members confuse development cost with construction cost. Over the last one year, construction cost has indeed gone down, but the land cost has not gone down that much. If you talk about flats built today, ie, ready for selection and to go in for occupation , they were bought by the Government several years back. At that time, the land cost was very expensive and the construction cost was equally high.

Column: 1183

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD RESALE FLATS

(Review of levy)



    3. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development if he will review the levy imposed on various types of Housing and Development Board resale flats in view of the current economic situation.

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to clarify that the resale levy is not imposed on HDB resale flats. If a person sells his first direct purchase HDB flat and buys a resale flat in the open market, he does not pay the resale levy. This is an important point. The resale levy is applicable only for lessees who have already enjoyed the first Government subsidy (either through the purchase of new HDB flats or the purchase of resale flats using the CPF housing grant) and intend to purchase another flat directly from HDB. In other words, he intends to take a second bite of the subsidy cherry.

    The objective of the resale levy is to ensure that the second housing subsidy is

Column: 1184

smaller than the first housing subsidy, which is something I am sure all Members will agree. The Government understands the needs of 3-room flat dwellers to upgrade to a bigger flat. Thus, it has structured the resale levy such that a lessee who sells a smaller flat, such as a 2-room or 3-room flat, pays a lower levy. Conversely, the levy imposed on the sale of a larger flat, like a 5-room or Executive flat, is higher than the 3-room or 4-room flat.

    The resale levy has effectively helped HDB to manage the demand for new flats from upgraders. As the objective to reduce the amount of subsidy for purchase of second flat from HDB is still valid, my Ministry does not see a need to review the resale levy now.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Is the Parliamentary Secretary not aware that all Government departments are reducing their fees? Can the same principle not be applied to the resale levy?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, I think the Member did not hear me correctly. If you sell your first flat which you purchased from the HDB some years ago, at least five years ago, and now you want to buy a resale flat, you do not pay the resale levy. You only pay the resale levy when you queue up and buy the next flat direct from HDB. Resale flats have indeed fallen in prices. So as a percentage of the smaller selling price, the absolute amount of the resale levy is already smaller. Apart from that, people who are eligible to sell today have already occupied their flats for at least five years. For those who are eligible to apply for a second flat, they would have stayed in the flat for 10 years. In other words, they would have bought their flats either in 1988 or 1993.

    In 1993, the price of a 3-room flat from HDB was only $44,000. In 1988, the price of a 3-room flat from HDB was only $41,000. Today, the resale price of a 3-room flat is approximately between $150,000 and $180,000. If you do a simple sum, there is a sizable capital gain, ie, $150,000-$180,000 minus the $40,000-odd and multiply that by 20% resale levy, which he need not pay until he gets the

Column: 1185

new flat. Of course, if he chooses this option he has to pay a 5% interest annually. In other words, my short answer is that no, we are not going to lower the resale levy.

    Dr Vasoo: Sir, despite his explanation, I do not understand the logic behind his argument that the prices of new flats have also gone up. Is the Parliamentary Secretary not aware that HDB has also moved towards market pricing? Is that not the direction? If that is the case, what is the basis of still maintaining the levy as imposed?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, because the selling prices of new HDB flats are still lower than the resale flats in the market today. Yes, resale prices have fallen by about 25% from the peak in 1996 and we have consequently adjusted the selling prices of new flats. But there is still a big gap between the price of a new flat and the price of an old flat. In view of the substantial market subsidy, the resale levy should stay.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, in view of the relatively lower resale prices of 3-room flats and the relatively higher prices of 4-room flats, in comparison to the market price now, would the Parliamentary Secretary consider waiving the resale levy for 3-room flats and help those who apply directly to HDB to upgrade to 4-room HDB flats?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, the resale levy for a 3-room flat is only 20%.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: It is money.

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Yes, correct, it is money and money is hard-earned. But maybe the Member for Hougang did not hear me. The resale price for a 3-room flat today is about $150,000-$180,000. The original selling price of a 3-room flat for those who are eligible to sell their flats today was only about $44,000. If you do a simple calculation, the capital gain is huge with over $100,000. Out of the $100,000 capital gain, which is tax free, you just pay 20% to the Government. You need not pay this amount until you get your new flat.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: How about comparing the selling price of a 4-room HDB flat now and $40,000, as mentioned by you, 20 years ago?

Column: 1186



    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, I have the figures here too. For 4-room flats, in 1988, HDB sold them at $65,000. In 1993, 4-room flats were sold at $109,000. Today, in spite of the downturn, 4-room flats are still being snapped up - in fact, they are the most popular units in the market - at $250,000.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I am talking about those who sold their 3-room flats and bought 4-room flats. I am asking for waiver of the levy for 3-room flats.

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, I think we are going off tangent here. These are upgraders. Your sympathy should lie with the first-timers, should you not? If we encourage upgraders to upgrade all the time, then the first-timers will be left behind. So we are talking about people who have already taken the first bite of the subsidy cherry. Why are we crying for people who have got a big bite of the cherry already? When a 3-roomer sells his 3-room flat and applies for a 4-room flat, the 4-room is sold at a heavy subsidy too, but the subsidy is now smaller because of the 22.5% resale levy. I think he did not get his perspective right, Mr Speaker.

    Dr Vasoo: Despite all that, is the Parliamentary Secretary willing to review the levy charges if the resale prices drop further?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, Government policies are never static. We always review policies as situations change. I thank the MP for Tanjong Pagar for his advice.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Parliamentary Secretary, in view of what he has just said, is it the Government's policy now to discourage people from upgrading, people who want to move from a 3-room flat to a 4-room flat if they think that the 3-room flat is inadequate? Is that the policy now?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Sir, the word "discourage" is not quite right. We give preference to first-timers, people who have never had the first bite of the cherry. For people who are living in 3-room flats today and want to upgrade to 4-room flats, we understand their aspirations. That is the reason why 4-room flat prices are benchmarked very affordably.

Column: 1187

BUY BACK SCHEME OF 3-ROOM HDB FLATS
(Stepping up of purchase)


    4. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board (HDB) will step up the purchase of 3-room HDB flats under the Buy Back Scheme.

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Selective Buy-Back of 3-room Flats Scheme was introduced on 19th May as one of the four measures taken by the Government to help low-income families own HDB flats. Eligible low-income families with household income not exceeding $1,500 per month can purchase the 3-room buy-back flats at heavily subsidised prices.

    In addition, some of these flats bought under the scheme are also offered for sale to lessees affected by SERS and tenants affected by Relocation Exercises, and for letting to rental applicants under the Transitional Rental Housing Scheme.

    HDB will continue to buy 3-room flats from the open market under the buy back scheme to cater to the demand from the low-income families and the housing needs under the other various schemes. Based on the current demand, there is no need to step up the purchase of such 3-room flats.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is it true that the HDB purposely refuses to buy back 3-room flats in opposition wards?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no truth in the allegation, as HDB actively buys back all good 3-room flats because we recognise that there is always a group of people who need 3-room flats even though their aspirations may be 4- or 5-room flats. So there is no truth in that statement.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what are the criteria for the HDB to decide whether to buy back a particular unit of 3-room flat from a particular area?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: The first criterion will be price. If Mr Low Thia Khiang's residents are selling a 3-room flat for $250,000, then

Column: 1188

the answer is no straightaway. But if the price is reasonable, then the next criterion is whether the 3-room HDB flat would be of use to somebody else, because we cannot keep empty stocks of 3-room flats around. These are taxpayers' monies. So we must buy a flat which is reasonably in demand. But we give the benefit of the doubt to the future buyers. In other words, we think that there will be a demand for this particular unit bought back from the market.

    Dr Vasoo: Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary willing to consider under the buy back scheme, particularly those cases that are upgrading, to enable them to move up to a 4-room flat?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: There is a huge demand in the resale market. Members must have read in the newspapers that the resale demand for this year has shot up to about 50,000 units. So there is no shortage of demand. The cases that we hear of people having difficulty in selling their 3-room flats boils down to price and location. For location, we can always discount it and sell it at the right price. There is always a clearing price for everything. Does he not agree?

    Dr Vasoo: I do not think I can agree because it depends on what price you set. It depends on whether there is a willing buyer and willing seller. May I ask, if there are upgraders who are, in fact, stuck for more than a year and they need to upgrade to bigger flats, could HDB consider such cases?

    Mr Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, if Dr Vasoo knows of such cases, could he please write to the Ministry and we will look at them carefully.

Column: 1188

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND

(Financing of budget deficit)


    5. Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the fact that measures to reduce business costs will lead to a loss of revenue for the Government, whether he will ensure that (i) Central Provident Fund (CPF) money will not be used to finance any part of the

Column: 1189

budget deficit that may arise; and (ii) sufficient safeguards are in place to prevent such uses of CPF money.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to assure Mr Ong that the Government has not and will not use CPF funds to finance budget deficits.

    Where it is necessary to incur operating budget deficits in order to pay for tax cuts and economic recovery expenditures, the deficits will be financed by drawing down from the pool of budget surpluses accumulated by the present Government.

Column: 1189

AMNESTY FOR DISMISSED FOREIGN WORKERS


    6. Mr Simon S C Tay asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the Government will offer recently dismissed foreign workers who have overstayed in Singapore a period of amnesty to report for repatriation to their home countries.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, foreigners whose work or visit passes have expired must leave Singapore and not stay on illegally here. Singapore is a small country with limited resources. We cannot afford to allow people to disregard our laws and stay on illegally, because such overstayers would impose a strain on our social system, leading to law and order problems.

    The Government has no intention to grant an amnesty to foreign workers who overstay. It would send the wrong signal to potential immigration offenders that they will be forgiven when they commit immigration offences in Singapore. This would erode the deterrent effect of our immigration laws and enforcement action, and lead to a more severe overstaying problem in the longer run.

    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, if a work permit is now cancelled in this present economic downturn, is there any grace period allowed at all for the person who turns himself in?

Column: 1190



    Assoc.     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move:

    `That this House endorses the strategies and policies set out in the Report of the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness, contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1998, as the basis for strengthening Singapore's competitiveness.'

    In May last year, the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness (CSC) was formed to critically assess Singapore's economic competitiveness over the next decade, taking into consideration global trends and development of existing and emerging competition. The CSC was tasked to identify problem areas and propose appropriate strategies and policies with a view to maintaining and strengthening Singapore's competitive position. The Committee has completed its work and released its Report on 11th November 1998. Copies of the Report have been circulated to hon. Members.

    When the CSC first began its work, the focus was on the next ten years. The onset of the regional economic crisis in July 1997 has, however, altered the economic landscape significantly. Given our open economy and significant

Column: 1210

linkages with the region, Singapore too has not been spared from the contagion despite our sound economic fundamentals. The sharp currency realignments have also weakened our competitiveness. The scope of the CSC Report was therefore expanded to propose measures to help the economy cope with the crisis. The Report hence includes both short- and long-term recommendations to improve our competitiveness.

Short-term Measures

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the regional crisis has significantly impacted our economic performance. Between 1st July 1997 and 21st November 1998, the S$ to US$ exchange rate and the Singapore stock market have fallen by 12% and 30% respectively. The GDP growth rate year-on-year has slowed from 7.8% in 1997 to 6.2% and 1.8% respectively in the first and second quarter of 1998. Third quarter growth was -0.7%, the first decline since 1985. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, the economy has been shrinking for two successive quarters. For the whole of 1998, Singapore's GDP growth is expected to be around 1/2-1%.

    Businesses have been hit, some sectors more than others, and more than 20,000 workers have been retrenched in the first three quarters as a result. The seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate has risen sharply from 2.3% in June to 4.5% in September this year. The coming quarters will be difficult for Singapore. We will continue to face weaker demand for our goods and services from the region which is struggling to recover from the severe economic crisis. The slowing momentum in the US and the EU will dampen demand further. As external demand accounts for more than two-thirds of our total demand, 1999 economic growth is expected to remain weak. MTI's preliminary growth forecast for 1999 is between -1% and 1%.

    A key concern is that the sharp currency realignments have eroded our cost-competitiveness. Our relative unit labour cost (RULC) has been rising gradually but steadily over the years. When the region was prospering, our rising RULC was a concern but not a critical problem. Now

Column: 1211

economic conditions have changed drastically in the region and we are competing for a global economic pie that is growing more slowly.

    Feedback from EDB indicated that some companies were facing pressures to pare prices or relocate production to other countries because of the cost differentials between Singapore and the regional countries. Our total exports to the US have fallen by 8.2% in the first 9 months of this year while all the other regional countries still managed to register positive export growth to the US. This is due largely to the weak performance of our electronics industry. Our market share of electronics exports to the US has dropped from 9.3% in the second quarter of 1997 to 7.3% in September 1998.

    For the short term, the key concern for Singapore is how to restore our competitiveness, help our companies to tide over the crisis and minimise further job losses. We also need to continue attracting investments to create new jobs for Singaporeans.

    Besides raising productivity which takes time, there are two main approaches to restore cost competitiveness in the short term. One approach is through currency depreciation. While MAS has been managing the S$ more flexibly in view of the regional crisis, competitive devaluation is not recommended. A weak S$, in the context of an open economy heavily dependent on imports, will translate into larger imported inflation. This would in turn erode any competitive gains from a currency devaluation. A depreciating currency would also erode confidence in the S$ as a store of value, impact our position as a financial centre and diminish the value of S$-denominated assets held by Singaporeans.

    The other approach which the CSC has recommended is to reduce business costs directly. This addresses the cost competitiveness head-on, without the disadvantages brought about by competitive devaluation. The Government took the same approach to tackle the 1985 recession, with great effectiveness.

    These measures should be implemented expeditiously to regain our competitiveness, minimise further job losses and position our economy to face intense competition as regional competitors struggle to export their way out of their economic difficulties. Besides the cost-cutting package, the CSC has also recommended measures to improve credit availability, seek out markets beyond the region, attract more businesses to Singapore and build up our capabilities.

    At the same time, we must not lose sight of the need to address longer-term challenges and take steps now to strengthen our competitiveness beyond the crisis.

    We need to take into account the long-term global trends which will have an impact on Singapore. Continued economic liberalisation, globalisation and rapid technological change will shape the competitive economic environment of the future. These global forces will not wait for the economic crisis to blow over.     Dr Lee Boon Yang:

    Singapore's wage costs are generally higher than other Southeast Asian economies and the NIEs, but lower than developed economies such as Japan, USA and European economies. While real earnings increased by around 4-5% annually over the past 5 years, productivity growth lagged, at 1-2% in 1996 and 1997.     15.     RAdm Teo Chee Hean:

    NUS and NTU are both committed to the promotion of research and development activities. They believe that the reputation of a university rests not only on teaching but also on its research excellence, and that a strong research standing attracts good academic staff and students. The universities have generally focused their research efforts on niche areas, including multi-disciplinary research, in which they can make an impact and which are of strategic relevance to Singapore and the region.

    In FY97, MOE allocated the universities a budget of $94.5 million to be used on research activities, including the purchase of equipment and recruitment of supporting manpower. This is almost 9% of the total budget allocated to the universities, and does not include the salaries of the academic staff which are covered under the universities' normal allocations. The universities also have access to research funding from other sources, eg NSTB, MOH, MINDEF, various foundations, and the industry. In total, they obtained another $68.8 million.

    There are some 19 national research institutes and research centres hosted by our universities. These institutions focus mainly on research that has high national relevance. NUS and NTU also have faculty-based research centres which nurture new niche areas in research.

    As part of our vision for Singapore to be a centre of excellence in education, our universities, together with various Government agencies, have recently initiated international collaborations at an institutional level. Cooperative arrangements have been formed with top institutions like MIT and Johns Hopkins. These seek to uplift the quality of research and teaching at our universities and to help them reach world-class status.

    At the individual level, the researchers in our universities have fostered strong links with industry and Government agencies. There are also numerous projects conducted jointly with researchers from top institutions around the world, eg Stanford University, University of Cambridge, Tsinghua University.

    The number of postgraduate research students has more than doubled in the past 5 years from 1551 in 1994 to 3956 this year. This is due to the aggressive recruitment drives undertaken by the universities to bring in the best students from Singapore and around the world. Selected undergraduates are also exposed to research work through specially tailored programmes in order to cultivate their interest in research at an early stage.

Successes in commercialising staff research cover a broad range of areas from waste water treatment to orthopaedic implant products to sensor systems.
